Oleg V. Deripaska, the second-richest man in Russia, further pushed the boundaries of his automobiles-to-aluminum empire last week when his holding company, Basic Element, bought 30 percent of the Austrian construction company Strabag for $1.6 billion.

Mr. Deripaska, 39, a former nuclear physicist, along with the other Russian billionaires known as oligarchs, is making ever-bolder forays outside Russia. In recent years, Basic Element has snapped up assets from Guyana to Britain.

At home, the oligarchs' fortunes are more uncertain. President Vladimir V. Putin is pursuing policies of state ownership in oil, automotives and aerospace. Mr. Deripaska, however, remains exceptionally well connected -- no small matter to the banks underwriting his billion-dollar deals. Forbes estimates his worth at $16.8 billion, behind only Roman A. Abramovich. As an example of his proximity to power, analysts of the oligarchy have pointed out that Mr. Deripaska is married to the step-granddaughter of the late former President Boris N. Yeltsin; Mr. Deripaska has played down the tie as irrelevant to his business activities. In any case, Mr. Deripaska did not play a public role in the funeral last week for Mr. Yeltsin.
